July 17th, 2014 - Next in the beer box is a collaboration with Victory, the Alt Route, an altbier (easy to guess from the name, I think) and a rare style here in San Diego. Im eager to try it by the time I dig in, noting the darker, auburn color and one finger of mostly white foam. The aroma is on the sweeter side, showing off some sweet cream, malt and caramel, like a lighter version of a red ale. It matches that style with smells of bubblegum and pomegranate too, though adding a twang that red ales dont typically have, and to which I might be attributing that pomegranate note. The palate is foamy on the front and then clears quickly, like fog in a sunbeam, revealing mild flavor of pomegranate. These make way for a more generic malt profile in the mid-taste and aftertaste, but with a lightness and crispness that gives the flavor some too to demand the tongues attention. I appreciate the light and crisp body, too, and should credit the hybridized style of brewing that Altbiers require for what is in effect both flavorful and refreshing.

12 oz bottle from 2014 Beer Camp series. Pours a burnt Amber color and topped by a small head of off white foam that fades quickly into the body below. The aroma shows notes of toasted bread malts, caramel, toffee, and light citrus fruit with some citrus hop bitterness on the back. The flavor follows and is mostly sweet from the caramel and toasted bread malts with some balancing citrus hop bitterness on the back end. Medium bodied with balanced carbonation that leads to a crisp, bitter lager finish. Decent enough but not my favorite style or of the series.

12 oz bottle, served in a shaker pint. Pours clear dark caramel with a reddish tint, creamy off-white head. Aroma is lightly sweet toasty caramel malt, pleasant oakiness on the back. Clean dry finish, lager-like as they note, light hops set nicely against the sweet malt. Honestly not my favorite style, but this is excellent.

Clear dark amber, almost brown, with a one-finger beige head and moderate lace. Aromas of toasted malt, caramel and toffee. Taste is similar mostly toasty malt sweetness with notes of bread and nuts and a touch of hops bitterness. Medium body and carbonation, smooth mouthfeel and a crisply bitter finish.
Super malts goin on here, make this brew very drinkable in a good way, enjoyed it but nothin that stands out
With Z, pours a dark brown color with a nice java head. Nose is rich and deep malt with some earthy hops. Taste is woody with heavy rich malt and a hoppy finish. Drinkable altbier. Quaff Score 7 / 10

Bottle part of the beer camp box. Pours a clear copper with a beige head and aroma of toasty malt, bready notes, and caramel. Taste is malt, lots of toasty malt with bread, caramel, and nutty notes as well as some hoppiness into the crisp, slightly bitter finish.
deep amber to reddish color; biscuity malt and floral hop aroma; bready, toasted malt flavor with slight burnt notes; well balanced

12oz. bottle. Toasty, nutty and mildly roasty malt aroma, some very light sweetness and fruitiness present along with notes of dark bread and faint cocoa. Clear medium copper-brown in color with a very fine, slight, light tan head. Flavor profile features plenty of bready, toasty, lightly brown sugary malt character, hazelnut, faint fruit and chocolate and a moderate dosage of clean hop bitterness and spicy, grassy hop flavors, perhaps some faint smoke and earthiness late. Smooth and finely effervescent on the palate with a medium body. Very nicely rendered and flavorful.

12 oz. bottle from SoHo Organic Market, Elizabeth City, NC. Dark orange pour with a frothy khaki head. Aroma of graham cracker and tangerine. Taste is malt forward with sweet toffee and nuts yet has a citrus and bitter hop finish. A fine example of the style even if it is a style that is not all that thrilling.
sampler 9/3 Unos Hamilton. This alt beer pours a light carmel brown. light hop nose wirh an easy mouthfeel and slughtly bitter finish.

Clear reddish brown in color... Aroma of dark stone fruits, caramel... Mouthfeel is refreshingly crisp, light pils hop finish, flavor is caramel, nutty malts... Solid, but nothing exciting...

Draft. Pours caramel brown with a thin white head that hardly holds on. A sweet aroma, like cranberries, over mild carbonation. I'd describe it as a slightly sweet brown ale. Tasty.

Poured a clear dark maple syrup color with a 2 finger foamy light beige head. There was a nice amount of carbonation bubbles rising up in the glass. The aroma was predominately caramal malt with a hint of some floral and citrus hops. The beer had a slightly thicker texture and a good amount of caramel malt flavor. A good amount of citrus hops flavor came thru in the middle leading to a more hop forward bitter finish. The head left a bit of light lacing throughout the glass.
Clear brown with a small beige head. The aroma has some caramel, toast, and some earthy hops. The flavor is pretty much the same, with a bitter finish. Pretty good.

Sampled on 9/1/2014. This altbier pours a dark brown color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel, nutty and sweet, with some grass. A medium bodied altbier. The malts are caramel, earthy and sweet. Some coffee and toffee flavors as well. The hops are herbal and earthy. Decent carbonation. Nice balance. A touch of hop bitterness at the finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
12 oz bottle. Poured a ruby color with a small off-white head. Aroma was caramel notes, some light wheat, light grass. Flavor was sweet, wheat, light earthy hops. Pretty enjoyable.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a brown amber with a one inch tan head that lasts. Taste is of roasted malt, grain, caramel and grass. Similar aroma. Has a decent body with a bitter and dry finish. Easy to drink, refreshing and enjoyable. Would buy a six pack of this again.

Bottle--really like a well made altbier and this didnt disappoint. Pours a dark ruby with a dirty, white head. The aroma was toffee and caramel with plenty of malt. Taste was mostly malt with caramel and surprise, some hops on finish. Light bitterness and carbonation. Total wine.
Toasted biscuit, subtle dark berry aromas, subtle forest floral aromas. Clear ruby-bronze with a lasting beige head. Dry caramel, toast, grassy hops. Light-medium bodied, dry finish.
Dark red amber color. Toasty aromas of caramel and toffee, coffee. Smooth, clean, crisp, well balanced.

12oz bottle from Bevmo 
Pours clear dark amber/brown with a small beige head, some lacing. Mild aroma of toasted malts, toffee and bready. Taste is toasted malts, fruity, bready, yeast and spicy hops 
Decent

12 oz bottle shared by ebone1988. Thanks Eric! Beer Camp #9. The pour is a ruby with some good lighter red around the edges and a nice white head with some great lacing. The aroma has a bunch of toasty caramel and nice nutty toffee. The malt is just really dominant. The flavor is also really malt based. There is a slight undertone of a hoppy bitterness to it, but it's really good. Light caramel and toffee and then a resounding bitterness. The mouth feel is a little thin and slick, and the carbonation is just light at best. The aftertaste is resoundingly bitter and dry

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

#9. Shared with koleminer20. Aroma is fruity, like fruit cocktail, grape, with a light Belgian vent. Appearance is beautiful, dark amber with an off-white head. Taste is malty, that fruit comes in, but then tons of hop. Mouthfeel is dry, intensely bitter aftertaste. Overall, its different. I like it.

12oz bottle via Beer Camp 12 pack from Berkeley Spirits. Pours a dark amber brown color with a nice two fingers of foamy light tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, toasted grain, caramel, nuts, and yeast. Taste mimics the nose.

Pours a deep dark copper penny color with a spider webbed lacing head. Not much aroma here. Slight dark fruit. A little bit of caramel sweetness. Flavor starts with a big malt character. A really nice feel. A touch of creamy thickness. A back taste of a small hop bitterness. Its quite good actually. Different. Subtle.

Bottle, as pictured. Part of the Beer Camp pack. Crystal clear amber brown pour. Sickly sweet scent, caramel. Very sweet and heavy on the malt for the flavor. Very drinkable and crisp. Nice beer. Style you dont see often.
Dark brown body with a thin head and adequate lacing. Aromas of nut, caramel, fig, and pine. Lingering bite on the finish. Interesting beer. Pretty decent effort.
This one was eh also. Aroma of malt. Dark pretty amber color. Flavor was malty and bitter,but not so enjoyable. Passable, but not great.

Tap at MacGregors. Reddish amber with lace. Nose of light caramel, grass, earth. Somewhat faint. Metallic, earthy flavor, big bitterness. Very soft caramel malts. Crisp and bitter. Needs more malt, and it has a weird matallic character. Otherwise a rather Uerige-like intensely bitter alt. Interesting for sure.

The aroma is nutty, toffee, caramel, wood. The appearance is deep copper, translucent, white head. The flavor is nutty, spicy, wood, toffee, raisins, caramel. The finish is resin, pine, grapefruit. Medium in body, smooth. Nice example of the style.

12 ounce bottle from the Beer Camp Across America pack, opened 7/26/14. Pours a clear copper color with a thin creamy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of toffee, caramel, nuts, raisin and a bit of an earthy note. The taste is caramel, toffee, raisin, nuts, treacle, spicy hops. Medium bodied, slight lingering bitterness.

Rich deep amber coloured body with hints of cola and light brown - very nice, all with a good two centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of crisp toasted malt, oatmeal, raisins, figs, yeast and a hint of molasses - very nice and crisp. Medium-bodied; Strong assertive toasted maltiness with a bitter and slightly offensive metallic and nutty flavour that shows strongly. Aftertaste has hints of metal, malt, alcohol, nuts, earth, grain, hops and even a twist of licorice - strong and pungent. Overall, a nice beer for the style with slightly more pungent flavours than usual, but in a good way. Deep and strong and if you like alts with more flavour than typical watered down versions, this will be perfect - great flavours throughout with a distinct complexity. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Harris Teeter here in Arlington (Pentagon Row), Virginia on 30-July-2014 for US$22,00/12 pack sampled at home a few blocks away in Washington on 28-August-2014.

12oz bottle. I consider 6.6% for an Alt to be pretty strong, but it works well here. One of the better examples of a Stateside Alt. Smooth, rich brown malt, touch of amber maybe. Nice bitterness upfront, which fades into a luscious sweet malt finish. Pretty excellent stuff, Id love to see Sierra do an Alt for a seasonal.

Clear medium brown color with a cream colored head. Aroma has caramel and nutty notes with some dark fruit. Flavor is dry and nutty. Medium bodied with a harsh mouthfeel. This is close to being really good but has this harsh mouthfeel/aftertaste that I just can't get past.

Bottle: Poured a clear deep brown color alt with a nice light brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of caramel malt with some earthy and citrus hoppy notes also noticeable. Taste is also dominated by loads of caramel malt with some earthy and citrus notes with medium residual sugars notes. Body is about average for style with good carbonation. Nice take on the style with great drinkability.

Deep carmel brown pour, clear and effervescent but so dark light doesnt completely pass. Quarter inch of beige head. Strong bready/doughy malt scent, creamy with ferric hints, rooty. Soft carbonation, average mouthfeel, clean finish. Malty, slightly sweet taste, carmel and/or toffee are in forefront, some banana esters, yeast is lager-esque but more bitter with earthy metallics, pine and floral hops add to the lingering bitterness. Good malty and slightly sweet beer thats easy going with unique bitterness. This beer does a lot and does it well - bitter, astringent, creamy, malty and sweet.

Bottle... Pours sparklingly clear and new-penny copper with a small, wispy, off-white head. Fantastic retention. The aroma is faint, but toasty  medium-roast to dark-roast malts and a lesser degree of breadiness. Full-bodied and a touch oily with soft carbonation. The flavor is toasty with heavy, crusty bitterness. All that aside, citrusy hops are the real star of this show. Lengthy, bitter, dry finish
Pours a clear ruby brown with tan head. Aroma has some grain, red fruit. Taste of rye toast, bitter hops and dark fruit. Pretty interesting brew.
Draft at Churchkey. Clear deep amber brown color, medium tan head. Aroma of nutty caramel. Taste is light toast, cocoa powder. Light body. OK.
Light copper, clean malt nose. Low head. Nice lagging. Sweet malt taste mixing in and out with bittering hops. Hop bitterness lingers. Clean crisp mouthfeel. Well balanced.

Tap. Opaque red brown color. Frothy white head. Fruity (plums, blackberries), at stones, dust wheat and sweet malts. Reserved, but well balanced. Medium-light body. Dry and semi bitter, with sweetness kicked in by some dull cherry notes and mild brown sugar. Solid hop showing, especially on finish.
a little more bitter than the style needs to be, but otherwise a pretty decent variation.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on July 31st 2014. Beer Camp 2 of 12.
Appearance: Pours a brown clear.
Aroma: Aroma of bread.
Taste: Taste of light nuttiness, light hop.
Palate:Light body, covers alcohol.
Summary: Decent beer.

2014 SN Beer Camp box from a bottle. Pours slightly cloudy dark rust with a disappearing off white head. Smells apple-like sweet with a little grass - nice. Tastes fruity, then bready, carmel-like malt, then finishes with a nice dose of bitter but tasty hops. Kind of like a hoppy, fall-fruity lager. Victory is known for using whole cone hops (instead of pellets). Not a fan of this style per se...but this beer is the most refreshing and best representation Ive tasted. Wish this was released later in October, November...it would have a cult following.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber body with a bit of a ruby hue under a nice frothy beige head that left some nice lacing. The nose is lightly fruity with some slight sweetness and a gentle hopping level. The flavor is very nice, just the right amount of fruitiness and sweetness, balanced by a great hop bitterness on the finish. This might be among the best domestic Alts that Ive had to date. Light bodied and very easy drinking with perfect soft carbonation. This is a great beer.

Pours a reddish brown with a slightly fizzy off white head. Aroma is fruity, citrus notes as it warms up, grains and toasted malt. Taste same as aroma with some moderate bitter notes. Palate is a medium body, with lively carbonation. Finish is fruity, toasted malt and grains, mild yeast and bread notes and mild bitterness with a slight nutty ending. Overall a clean crisp and good drinking brew.

Pours a reddish light chestnut brown with a one finger tan head with nice lacing. Aroma is of toasted malts, bready malts, caramel, sweet malts, toffee, apple juice, grassy hops, and light pine. Taste is about the same as the aroma. Has a medium body with a semi creamy mouthfeel and a semi bitter semi dry, medium-long finish. Overall, a tasty Altbier that is nice and hoppy for a style that is too malty for my hop head tastes.

4oz pour at Churchkey DC pours a clear amber with some soapy, lacing white head. Nose is crackery, some fall fruit, some mild citrus, hints of herbs. Flavor is malty, lightly bitter, some black tea, mild yeast. Clean finish. Solid for the style.

Red brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel, a bit of dark fruits, nuts, and light roast. Taste of caramel, roasted malts, some nuts, earthy yeast, dry hoppy finish.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 8-21-14. Juicy, bready aroma features scents of malted milk balls, lemon, toffee, pastry, and bread. Nice, pleasant smell features some dryness and citrus. Pours medium brown, reddish dark amber, or maroon in color. Clear and highly effervescent liquid. Moderate amount of beige to cream-colored head. Produces good, long-lasting lacing. Bitter and dry taste features flavors of molasses, brown sugar, lime, kumquat, and other citrus, pretzel, salt, pumpernickel bread, bran muffin, and a touch of rum. Interesting and tasty. Medium body. Soft and reasonably lively in the palate. Overall, really good and highly enjoyable.

On tap, pours slightly hazy mahogany color with medium to large off white head, lasting with lots of tiny bubbles. Body is thin and well carbonated. Notes are cherry and sweet tasting malt, bitter citrus hops, rye and some toasty grain. Pretty solid with regards to flavor and aroma.

Pours dark mahogany into a shaker. Off-white head with excellent retention recedes to coat surface. Dark caramel and pit fruit aromas. Sweet dark caramel and dry bitter earth front to back. Lasting dark resin finish.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Duvel tulip. Bottled on 6/3/14 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours a medium coffee brown with orange-copper highlights and a 1-2 finger foamy light cream colored head. Decent head retention and lacing. (3.75)

Smell: Sweet caramel and candied malt with just a touch of hops and spices. (4)

Taste: Mildly bitter citrus and bready malt up front followed by pilsner malt in the middle before ending with a blast of hoppy bitterness featuring a nice mix of lemon zest and pine at the finish. Aftertaste is bitter and long-lasting. (3.75)

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. (3.75)

Drinkability: Good drinkability. You could drink a couple of these without any trouble. (3.75)

Overall: Solid beer overall. I took off a few points for not conforming to style. Its definitely a bit hoppy for an altbier, but thats okay for this hophead. Its definitely worth trying. (3.5)
Bottle... Poured deep, amber-ish/mahogany/brown with a mild forming head. Malty, nutty, sweet, with a hint of earthy hop spicing. Some fruit notes and charred grains and fruit.
bottle in beer camp box, this was good, i like the toasty flavors that come in an alt beer. This one had them, dry light finish, good all-around.

Pours a hazy amber with a short, off-white head and some lacing. It has a mild aroma of dark fruit and some earthy hops. The flavor is malt and some dark fruit up front with a clean, dry and slightly sweet finish.

deep brown .. . fantastic head .. . heavy fog on the moors tonight .. . mild sweetness, tin, unsweetened maple, and old toffee .. . nice bitterness .. . a nice alt, balanced but i find alts boring so take this, whatever .. . .  Went to my nieces elementary school field day last week. I won every single event.  Every. Single. Event.

Appearance: A dark mahogany body on this beer with a very fluffy white head. Although the beer is dark, it is easy to see the clarity of the beer by the crispness of the shadows cast by objects on the other side of the glass. It looks perfect.

Aroma: Not a lot of aroma on this beer. It has a slightly spicy hop character and that is it.

Taste: This has a light caramel sweetness up front followed by a bread crust-like flavor which is ended by a mint flavored hop aftertaste. A bit of pine needle lingers around the edge as well. I can see where the interpretation of flavors would lend itself to an Altbier.

Overall: This was a decent beer but not that memorable. It was worth drinking and worked well as an Altbier, but it just felt like subtle nuance was missing from it.

On tap at the Knick. Light roast, mild hops - a nice Altbier nose. Coppery brown clear with thin head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Decent malt flavor with light bitter hop finish. A tad soapy with clean nutty after.
Pours a dark copper to almost brown. This white head that leaves some lacing. Light malt aroma with hints of vinegar. A bit of a grainy malty flavor.

Bottle, still working through the 12 pack after a month and a half. Pours a light brown with moderate head. Aroma is nutty and slightly grassy. Taste is very light, grain, mild roast, oats and a slight nuttiness at the finish. Overall, mild beer that doesnt do much for me.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Dark amber beer, slightly chunky cream colored head. Aroma is nutty, lager like, faint metallic and fruit. Taste is rich, malty lager, with a light citrusy ending, finish is hoppy bitter. Body is light, but not thin, carbonation fine, good balance. If this is "lager", bring it!

12 ounce bottle

A solid altbier is pretty true to the style. Despite that I find it to be a bit boring after about a half glass. Im not sure if a little age took the edge out of the hops but it lacked the spirit of a true Victory beer. Thankfully though it has enough redeeming characteristics to be average or slightly above average.

Aroma / Appearance - A fluid coppery base with white crisp head brighten the glass. Malt, red vines, caramel, and heavily malted iced tea hang in the air with a warm presence. A bit thicker than expected it is not a subtle altbier.

Flavor / Palate - The chewy mouthfeel tastes like biting into a fresh warm loaf of sourdough bread. A splash of nuttiness, caramel, and stale chocolate adds nice depth. The finish weakens the experience. With a bland touch the beer peters out rather than finishing strongly. I would not object to another bottle but this is one of the weaker offerings in the Beer Camp box.

Bottle. Earthy grain aroma with notes of caramel malt and hops. Pours caramel colored with decent off-white head with good retention and lacing. Earthy, caramel malt flavors to start. Finishes dry with hops and rye flavors coming through. Not bad.

Pours dark brown / coca cola colored with a light off white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, faint grape, earthy hop. Flavor is sweet malt, wood, caramel, earthy hop bitterness on the finish. Medium body, fairly dry finish.

Nice roasted malt aroma, maybe slight sweet, with some floral hop balance. Taste is malty, maybe some slight cocoa flavors in the roasted malt taste. Has a bitter dry finish with the hops. Not sweet flavor, finish is the piney resin hop but not as noticeable with the malt. Nice moderately dark malty beer.

Kind of a light altbier, without much of the sharp bitter grain as some of the best of the style. Some crispness in finish. Pours maroon with good head and lacing. Tap at Churchkey.

Bottle: brown pour with medium sized ecru head. Aroma is caramel with a bit of toasted grain and a little cider. Flavor is sweet caramel with some dry toasted grain, a bitter grassiness, and a grapefruit rind bite. Nice mix of bittersweet flavor, ending with a lingering bitter note.
Good complexity without being overwhelming. Flavors of caramel, whole grain, citrus fruits and peels, mild yeast and a light peppery finish. Loght and crisp, great for a warm day.

Beautiful deep translucent red pour with a generous cappuccino head. Caramel, cherries, floral hops come through on the nose. Also a little bit of spice. Dark cherries and caramel with some roasted malts are prominent in taste. Crisp medium mouthfeel with a lingering light coffee dark chocolate cake finish. Surprisingly filling.

12oz bottle from savor growl. Deep copper-brown pour with thin soapy off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramel, citrus, floral. Tastes are rye, caramel, yeasty, pine, toasty, grain, pepper, nutty. Lot going on and well balanced.

12oz bottle pours a reddish brown color with an finish off white head that leaves light lacing. Smells of caramel, dark fruit and citrus. Tastes of the same things in the smell. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with decent carbonation and a semi dry finish. This is a nice hopped up version of a classic alt style beer. Not bad but not something Id enjoy drinking all the time.

Smells and looks great, not much to the taste however. Pours a great ruby red with a white head. Smells of cherry and plum. Taste however is not super interesting. Very watery. Starts with some plum, and ends with a bit of bitterness. Had in the bottle.
Bottle. Caramel malt, hay, and light astringent alcohol aroma. Copper with large light tan head. Sweet caramel malt and lightly bitter/astringent herbal grass flavor. Light body. Nice altbier.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured clear, reddish brown, small off white head and some spotty lacing. Aroma is malty, a bit of roast notes and some fruit notes too. Taste is sweet, fruit and spicy, bitter hoppy finish. Good beer.

12oz bottle from Spirits Brick. Poured a deep rustic brown with some red hues and a smaller white head. Aroma of syrup, nut shells, slight sour citrus. Flavor of nutts, wet bread crusts, toast, super dry molasses. Meh.
Not bad, but just nothing to grab your attention. My least favorite of the 12. Malty slightly raisiny and hoppy nose and flavor. A touch dusty on the nose. Weakfish ending to a great mixer...

Poured from bottle into taster glass. Reddish brownish color, with thin white head that vanishes quickly. Smell has some roasted malts. Taste maybe some malts and a little hops. Kind of bitter finish. Not really much too much to it. Medium bodied with a little carbonation. Overall, not that exciting, but certainly not bad. It kind of grew on me as I drank it, I think it just had to warm up a little bit.

At first I was going to say this was the blandest of the Beer Camp box (which isn't the worst thing, it's been pretty awesome). But it grew in me. Not my favorite style, but you can tell it's well done.

Bottle shared by Mr Barleywine, Thanks Mike! 
Deep copper color, bready pilsner, toffee and caramel. Lots of earthy hop flavor. Decent beer, a bit hoppy for an alt, but I guess that makes it better than a regular alt.

Poured into Alt glass a deep cooper with lasting thin bubbled off white head. Med body and co2. Curtain lace. Aroma was muted, maybe because Alt glass not best for de looping aromas but it was malt grains. Taste was better than aroma but still malty and on the bready side. At sip its sweet but it bitters towards the finish. On the dry side with a crisp finish. Enjoyed.

Bottle. Clear amber orange color with a white head. Aroma is malty, sweet with some roasty nutty notes. Flavor is dry, dusty, leafy and quite grainy.

12 oz bottle. Pours ruby amber with a big meringue head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is subdued - grainy leathery malts.

The flavor is grainy nutty malts with a fairly bitter tarry finish. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, kind of bland grainy nutty malts with an odd bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle. Pour is an opaque, deep brown with a decent amount of off-white head. Is caramel, citrus, brown sugar and hops. Taste is slightly malty and nutty with with some malt bitterness that gives way to hop bitterness. Medium mouthfeel, okay but not blown away.

12oz bottle 8/13/14 (Beer Camp 12pk)-44° in Mug-Pours a light brown with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweetness, and slight dried fruits. Taste of the same. This light to medium bodied is a nice tasting brew but not my cup of tea.

2014 Beer Camp Across America Tour, mixed 12pk. 12oz bottle. Carolina Blue colored label. Beer pours light brown color, thin tan head. Aroma of wort, sweet malts. Flavor is of deep toasted grains, dried brown sugar, date sugar, all without sweetness. A very nice German Braun Ale. Finishes with a wooded bitterness. (4148)

Clear chestnut pour with a 1 finger, tan head. Aroma is bready, cereal and toasty, light tree fruit and cooked apple and berry notes. Flavor is nice and toasty up front, bread crust, caramel, tree fruit, stone fruit, and berry esters, nice citrus notes, and some herbal bitterness. Medium body, creamy to syrupy entry, medium carbonation and dry finish. Good stuff, surprisingly bright and fruity, but with a nice toasty, kinda nutty backbone.

On tap at Warrens Ale House in Wheaton, IL., and dispensed to a tulip, showing a clear mahogany/brownish copper color, with a frothy layer of off white/light tan head foam that left lacing as wavy spray on the glass. The nose was toasted, with touches of dried & dark fruit, and a bit of dark caramel sweetness. Medium bodied, the taste was similar notes as the aroma, with decent maltiness, then a lingering combo of earth, rind, & pepper bitterness that became more pronounced into the finish, with enough harshness to the astringency to lessen the drinkability, imo.

Bottle at home. Pours clear brown with a large, creamy and foamy off-white head, long retention with good lacing. Aroma is toasty, caramel and nutty malt, bready with light notes of dates, leaves and earthy hops. Flavor is sweet toasty and nutty malt, light caramel notes and dark fruits, light earthy hops and medium bitterness with a sweet finish. Medium-full body and medium carbonation with light alcohol warmth.

12 oz bottle poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Bottled 6/3/14. Clear ruby color with 1.5 fingers of off-white head. Aromas of caramel, wheat spices. Tastes of caramel, sweet malt, wheat, spices, bitter hops. Medium body with a dry finish.
Pours a dark brown. Nose is caramel, grass, and bitter hops. Not entirely great smelling. Taste is lingering bitter hops, caramel, and pennies. Least favorite of the pack so far.

12oz bottle. Large beige head atop clear copper body. Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, some caramel, light grapefruit/earthy, faint cardboard. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some honey, grapefruit, light lime. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

Average beer. Aroma was kind of nasty. Diesel and notes of roasted malt. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a thin tan film for a head. Taste was drinkable. Tasted like gasoline with a roasted malt backbone. Very poor representation of this style. Decent carbonation. Blah

text: As of late I can not find the time to take tasting notes of each beer I sample. I would like to track and record my thoughts of each so I will just use the simple scoring rubric until more time is available.

Dark brown pour with an off-white head. The aroma is very malty with some toffee notes as well as a bit of grass. The flavor is also very malty. I get some strong toffee as well as some light, dusty chocolate and grass. There is a decent amount of hop bitterness. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Pours a clear deep amber color with pull candy colored head. Faint toffee and fruit notes. The scrubby and hot features tend to create a harsher mouthfeel. At least early on. Blends well to create a strawberry toffee quality. Plenty of bitterness at the rear of the palate.
Clear bronze, decent sized white head. Smells like pine and molasses, plus a wee bit of tobacco. Taste is molasses and pine - more woody, piney notes than I was expecting, actually. Pretty enjoyable.

Bottle. Amber/copper pour, tan head. Some retention/lace. Aroma of dark fruit, clove, toffee, spice. Taste is sweet, clove, dark fruit, toffee, spicy. Palate is higher carbonation, slick, sweeter finish.

Pours clear medium brown with a creamy beige head, excellent retention, very fine lacing. Aromas of grass, toast, dough, and ripe banana. Medium body, velvety, dry. Mildly sweet, deep lingering medium bitter finish. Really hits the spot.

From the Beer Camp series by Sierra Nevada, this pours a deep mahogany into the glass with a solid eggshell head that diminishes to simple trace lacing. The nose is of barley and yeasty esters. Flavors are nut skins, stone fruits, grains, lots of biscuit, and finishes with a nutty bitter. Medium-bodied and satiating to the palate, Very good altbier here.
Pours a dark amber brown with a big white head. Aroma of caramel malt, slight banana esters, bitter hops. Taste is smooth, malty, English hops. Very mild.

On tap at Butcher & the Boar pours a clear reddish/brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma of sweet fruits and caramel malt. Taste of hop bitterness and dry caramel toffee malts with some fruitiness.

Deep amber body topped by a creamy tan head. Excellent head retention and terrific lacing. Roasty caramel and toffee malt aromas. Sweet malt, tangy citrusy hop flavors that end with a lingering dry bitterness. Nicely balanced.

Bottle. Rusty amber with a tall, foamy tan head. Aroma is fruity and sweet with caramel, toasted malt, toffee notes and soft hop notes. Taste is caramel, toasted malt, soft fruit, floral hops, tea notes, toffee and soft hops. Body is medium with a moderate, bubbly carbonation. From the bottle. Light, clean grain on the aroma with background hop bitterness. Taste is lightly toasted grain with pine and hop bitterness and some clean lager flavors. Clean mouthfeel; dry finish. Nicely made beer.

Bottled. Pours a typical copper with a small white head and good lacing in a dimpled mug. Bready malt aroma, with grape kool-aid fruitiness. Flavor was inoffensive, but not a lot going on. Cracker and a little pepper, with soft carbonation and medium body.

On tap at Baileys Taproom, pours a hazy dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is pretty much non-existent. Flavour is a little more lively, with notes of toasted nuts and dry crusty bread. Pretty boring stuff but well-enough made. Decent.

Biscuit à la mélasse, agrumes, caramel léger, malt rôtis dans un liquide croustillant mais confortable. Bonne amertume et finale sèche. Jadore ce style plus traditionnel ou américanisé comme cette version.

Bottle. Clear amber-chestnut color with a one-finger off-white head and good lacing. Nutty, malty, caramel aroma. The flavor is nice and balanced, really nutty with some toffee notes and a mild citrus hop finish. Medium-bodied with a crisp palate. Good beer.

Bottle. Deep but brown through the side of the glass but, clear brown if you look straight down. Big raisin notes on the aroma and taste with some citrus hops peaking through. Warm, toffee, nutty flavors too. A bit sweet on the finish.

Beer camp collaborative 12 pack. Drinking them by ibu. Lowest to highest. Great character here. Quite drinkable.

12 oz. bottle from Wilburs. Appearance: 2 fingers tan head, amber red color, clear, lacing is great, head does not last too long. Aroma: light grape, malty sweet, caramel, nutty, light biscuit. Pours light brown with a nice head. Aroma is brown sugar and raisins. Flavor is sweet and tart, like a good asian dipping sauce.

12 ounce bottle from the Beer Camp box. Malty with dark color. Toffee. Caramel. Well balanced.
Nice balance of smoke malt and hop in the style of arrogant bastard. My favorite of the 12 pack thus far.

12 ounce bottle poured to a dimpled mug. I don't see many altbiers in the store, so I was pleased to see this turn up in the Beer Camp pack. Nice balance of malts & sweetness, with a slightly bitter finish.
bottle rumcake. banana. toasted caramel. grape drank. dry bitter resin hop character. okay.

Bottle from Beer Camp Pack. Pours a pretty amber-red with a frothy, cream-colored head. Nose is toasted malts, some grassy and some white grapefruit hops. Flavor starts with nutty malts, then immediately goes to white grapefruit, then more assertive pine hops. Light to medium in body with lingering piney hops in the finish.

Drought. Copper red color with creamy largge off-white head, very little malt aroma, slightly bitter roasted malt taste, low carbonation, long finish with bitter aftertaste. Interesting collaboration product.
I probably dont have an adequate understanding of what a good Altbier is supposed to taste like.
Bottle. Nose is a very weird green apple, cider like, sulfur and vegetal combo. Weird. Pour is a deep red. Taste isnt much better but a tad bitter and harsh.

Served on tap in a pint glass 

 Appearance  The beer is served a brown-amber color with a one finger head of tan colored foam. The head fades moderately quickly, leaving a bit of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell- The aroma is biggest of a slightly sweet and roasty smell with the sweet aromas being of toffee and brown sugar and the roasted being of a roasted malt smell mixed with some toasted bready smells. A little bit of a citrus and grassy hop are there as well, but these are quite light in comparison to the others.

 Taste  The taste begins with roasted malt flavor with some hints of a brown sugar and toffee. The sweeter flavors initially increase in intensity all while the roast remains relatively constant and is joined by some bready flavors. This soon changes however as the roasted flavors increase at the expense of some of the sweet with some more woody and slightly rummy flavors coming to the taste as well. A bit of a toast flavor as well as some lighter hop flavors of a more herbal and grassy taste come to the tongue along with a resurgence of some sweet flavors with a decent showing of brown sugar and caramel, which end up leaving a moderately sweet and more roasted bready flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body is a bit on the thicker side with a carbonation level that is on the slightly lower side. For the sweet and slightly more roasted flavors of the brew the feel is quite nice and accentuates these flavors well.

 Overall  A rather good alt. A nice level of roast that complements the sweet rather nicely and leaves one with just enough bitter from the hop to cleanse the palate a bit.

Bottle; Pour is deep mahogany with a modest, fine bubbled khaki head into this glass. It retains on the average side, with sticky lacing presence. The nose is toffee initial, moving to grassy hops, with light citrus notes moving forward. The silky smooth smoke / nuttiness barely sticks its head out. My first thought was that this was lacking the malt depth I was looking for, while the bright hop elements took over - but frankly the description tells the story well. The marketing on this particular brew is applause worthy - the naming, style, beer series, and creation are molded beautifully. Unfortunately its not as wonderful a success as a finished beer. Anyway - its vibrant from the hop presence - light citrusy sweet notes meld with mellow malty undertones - its bittering and a little dry, with more fruit and velvet near the finish line. A nice attempt either way.

12 oz bottle from beer camp mix pack. Pours a translucent roan brown with a small beige head that has good retention. The aroma is mild with dried fruits, brown sugar and roasted barley. The taste is conjures images of cola, but without the vanilla, nor the sweetness. A bit of earthy bitter nuts round out the sides and back. The palate is light but effective and the carbonation is lively. Finishes medium in duration and dry. Overall: Very tasty Alt--me likey.
Brown pour from rattle. Malts, not too sticky, little bit of earth. Pretty darned good.

Clear dark mahogany/ruby with a thin foamy, tight off-beige head. Caramelly malt forward nose with an earthy lagered biscuit overtone. Nutty earthy flavor with a cracker-dryness and a crisp caramalt and dark sweet toast crust finish. Medium earthy bitterness throughout. Toasty and earthy sweet with a punchy bitterness, but not enough to take away from the malty sweetness.

This brew is a clear dark chestnut color with a medium fluffy white head that diminishes gradually. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, fruit and hops. Medium-bodied with flavors of bready malt, caramel and grassy hops. Slight fruit in the background. The finish is sweet with a roasted malt aftertaste. Decent Altbier overall.
Bottle from the beer camp boxed set. Pours a deep dark color with a malty nutty flavor and aroma. Decent
Nose is caramel and bready malts and some citrus hops. Clean, fairly alt-like core but too bitter for me in the end. Alright.

My most anticipated of the bunch. Pours a sultry amber/ruby with a tall, buoyant khaki head that settles slowly and leaves some foamy lace. Nose involves some toasted malt, cherries, brown sugar, and some herbal, woody, and fruity hop notes. Fairly sweet, a bit more bitter. Medium bodied, oily, with a fruity and toasty bitter finish. I enjoyed this a lot. A nice rendition of an altbier, with plenty of character and subtlety as well as drinkability. High hopes were met.

12oz bottle pours semi clear dark red brown with a finger of head. Nose is light bready malt, oats, whole wheat grain, touch of pine. Taste is bready malt, multi-grain, wheat, oats, light pine, light fruit, mild bitter. Finish is mild bitterness, malty bready fruit and hints of pine.

On tap at Beer Camp Across America southeast. Pours a clear copper with nice white head that leaves light lace. Aroma is malty up front, German yeast, bready dough and some nuts. Taste follows, with a hint of floral hops on the back end, earthy and malty. Very nice for the style, and you wouldnt expect anything less from these two breweries.

Btl pours clear light amber color with ruby highlights,nice fluffy off white head that lingers leaving an abundance of lace on glass. Aromas of herbs, flowers, toast, bread and a hint of alcohol. Tastes of sweet caramel, dark bread, and floral, earthy hops.Medium body,creamy yet slick mouthfeel,lively,tingling carbonation and a slightly dry finish. The malts in this beer shine. This Alt has very crisp and clean flavors making it nice and easy to drink!

Bottle to pint glass. The pour is ruby brown with a one finger cream head that lasts for quite a bit. The aroma is strong malt, some nuttiness, and a floral hop. The taste is more hop forward than the aroma but has a woody, earthy nut quality that balances nicely. The finish is dry with a building hop bitterness. Overall a nice beer.

Dark Red Brown pour could be a bit more red good retention on foamy head. Bright caramel, tang of cherries. Tastes woody, made from dry yeast (pondy), caramel, some tobacco, astringent. Drying palate.
Pours a very nice mahogany with slight white foam. Kinda nutty and hippy on the nose. "Slightly sweet malt body supported by citrusy hop flavor..." Haha. Delish.
Bottle. Pours reddish brown white head. nose/taste of caramel, light toast, cocoa and dried dark bread. Lighter medium body.

12oz. bottle from Sierra Nevada Collaboration Beer Camp 12 pack. Head is smallish sized, tan, but what little head there is remains for thick lacing. Color is dark amber and perfectly clear, not a whisper of fog in this beer. Aroma is very light, tough to get much here .... perhaps some light nuts and toasted malt. Flavor is pleasantly sweet with a welcoming bitterness but not overly so. Finish is also slightly sweet but a mellow sweetness that leaves you wanting to take another sip. Very inviting beer, very enjoyable. Nice offering. I liked this.

The beer is a dark, brown-ish copper color. It is quite clear. I cant even see a touch of haze to the beer. The head is beige and built up fairly well on the initial pour. Theres moderate lacing. Decent retention. Nice enough looking alt. The aroma is toasty bread with a base of caramel sweetness. Mild nuttiness. Smells like somewhere between an amber and a brown ale. Mild to moderate citrus hoppiness, fades a bit over time. Very mild chocolate. Very light medicinal note. Taste starts out medium sweet with some caramel and bread. A bit washed out and simply sweet. A nice enough nutty note with moderate bitterness in the finish. Fairly toasty, again. It just doesnt quite have that rich but clean feeling like some versions of the style. Mouthfeel is smooth, normal carbonation, a bit slick. Not bad, not great.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 6/3/2014. Pours crystal clear deep ruby red color with a 2 finger dense and rocky light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with some light streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, toast, toffee, brown bread, pear, apple, light roast, light herbal, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, yeast ester, and light hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of caramel, toast, brown sugar, brown bread, light roast, light fruitiness, herbal, floral, and yeast earthiness. Fair amount of earthy herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, brown sugar, brown bread, light roast, light fruitiness, herbal, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice robustness and balance of dark/bready malt, earthy hops, and light yeast flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, fairly crisp, and lightly creamy/sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very good altbier style. Good balance and robustness of dark/bready malt, earthy hops, and light yeast flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.

Deep red pour with a single finger head. Aroma of sugar, caramel. Really not much aroma here. Medium mouth. Flavor is pretty interesting. Grain shines through, ends dry and bitter. Bright floral notes. Biting carbonation with no lace present on glass. Mouth is medium bodied.

Biscuity malt aroma to start, pours a clear reddish-amber with a thin off-white head. Sweet malts with some fruit notes is the initial flavor, with a blast of citrus, then a lingering bitterness. Im not sure the hop flavors really work with the malts selected, and I wouldnt pick this one up again.

Pours a clear brown with a white head. Aroma is malty with light hoppy notes and bits of caramel throughout. Taste is moderately sweet with bitterness throughout and a medium duration. Overall, a delicious offering.

bottle, from the Beer Dispensary, Apex. Packaged 6/01/14. good aroma, sweet. yeasty. bread, caramel, grass, grapefrui. clean brownish orange color, good head and lace. sweet bitter flavor, creamy oily mouthfeel, bitter finish. nice alt. maybe little more citrus/grapefruit than I get in most alts, but rine drinking. strong bitter finish. good beer, not sure Id have alot of it, but enjoying it right now. flavor my favotrite part, aroma wasnt as strong, nice body too.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Strong pils malt with caramel and light toasted malt character. Spot on style. Hopping is not over done or too bitter. Citrus and pine from hops compliments malt profile nicely.

Bottle from the 12-pack.

Getting through this pack is turning into a bit of a slog. I think the hard part is that I have to sit down and rate every beer I drink. But Im getting there. Anyway this one pours quite dark with red-orange highlights and an off-white head. The nose is nutty, with hints of orange, metal, and straw. Malt flavors are quite full, with plenty of nut and a whisper of milk chocolate and some burnt toast with a splash of grapefruit coming on late. Another perfectly good beer from the 12-pack.

12 ounce bottle. Garnet color with a large foamy beige head. Subtle toasted malt nose. A bit of brown sugar and apple cider vinegar as well. Delicious semi-sweet malt flavor has a soft smoky character and silky mouthfeel. Lots of wonderful nuances here, including spicy citrus hops, vanilla and pecan.
Bottle from the sampler pack. Clear reddish amber pour with a small soapy head. This is excellent in the style. Crisp, fruity, rich hop elements, and some caramel sweetness.
beautifully executed. the proto-forefathers of modern American brewing go to the undeniably essential roots of brewing tradition and make this AMAZING beer.

Dark orange, almost a copper color. Minimal head, but but a murky complexion. Once the sweat is wiped from the glass, its a little clearer, but not by much.

Malt aroma is sugary and beautiful, but with a certain Euro crispness. There is a certain hint of metallic/battery in the nose, but it enhances instead of detracting. The hop is a mild, grassy accent.

Flavor has sugary malts. There is a nutty dryness. There isnt a ton of hop -- what there is seems like the Euro/bittering variety. But the malt components (sweet sugars, nutty grains) balance each other enough.

The feel is a bit dry and sandy. Has an almost coffee aftertaste; mocha? Its a very "plesant" beer. Very easy to drink, full of flavor, and might even please a non-beer drinker.

Bottle at home with my dad. Pour is deep brownish-red with a frothy cream head and great lacing. Husky, caramelly, dark fruits, bread, spicy hops and grassy aroma. Taste is husky, caramel malts, biscuit, light cookie malt, grassy, noble hoppy, and cereal with a medium bitter finish. Medium body with crisp carbonation. Pretty good.

Sampled at Beer Camp 2014 @ Navy Pier (Chicago, IL). Pours a nice copper brown hue, some fiery red in the light with some hazy body in the middle. Frothy tannish head is small, mellow layer sticks around and laces small. Aromas are a bit sticky, carmelized malts, toffee and a bit of brown sugar. Some earthiness, mellow florals and bitter earthy hops. Some touches of nut and soil. Initial is similar, lighter end of medium bodied with some wet paper, biscuits and caramel. A bit of earth, gentle spiciness and bitter hops start to hit. Backend is a bit dry, spicy as we hit the backend. Earth with a decent dose of hops. Not so bad if a bit ho hum. Ok beer, looks great.

Clean and copper amber pour with a profusely dense mocha tan head. Very nice aroma with rustic and earthy malt notes up front. Lightly grainy with a malty sweetness and hints of celery seed. Nice and round flavor, just the lightest hint of apple skin at the front with a full and malty following. Leans out in the body and finish. Lightly bready with a touch of sweetness. Medium light body and dry on the finish.
Pours a reddish brown with off-white head. Caramel and some malt on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes sweet. Not really digging this one.

Wow, such a length dissertation. Its a red (plum) beer with a white head that smells like your average malt profile. The flavor is the same with a fruitiness following. Its good taste doesnt make up for the harsh palate.
Medium brown in the glass with a light tan head. Toffee and toast malt aroma. Nice herbal hop notes with more toasted malt character. Really well done.

Although all the breweries in this case are excellent, I was most excited about this collaberation. Dont have much experience with this style. Hops are present but very malty. Sweet dinish with a touhg of alcohol.

Bottle from Beer Camp Across America pack into tulip glass, deep rusty red color with tan head. Aroma of earthy funk, grain and caramel malt. Taste adds notes of nuttiness, light chocolate, toast, faint berries and light fruity hops. Medium body, low-moderate carbonation, creamy, dry with fruity malty hop finish. I havent had many altbiers but this is quite tasty.

Initially the aroma was rather barnyard like - hay - manure, but as it warmed, caramel notes delveloped. A clear, but dark copper hue supports an ivory ring and moderate lacing. The malt character is subdued while the hops side of the equations seems to dominate. Medium body and medium carbonation. Overall, a rather bland beer. Meh

12 oz bottle -- bottled on date 3 June 2014 -- served in a snifter.

Pours deep mahogany in color; clear; good small head soon reduces to a partial coat but leaves good lacing. 

Aroma: slight dominance of malt base by spicy hops. 

Flavor: Medium and dark roasted malts up front with a relatively (for style) hefty dose of spicy hops kicking in mid-taste and buidling to the mildly hoppy and slightly bitter finish. Well balanced. 

Feel: medium body and medium soft carbonation. Semi-dry finish. 

O: a slightly hoppy but definitely recommended version of the style. Improved with warming.
Warm, malty mouthfeel with some flecked barley. Maybe a touch of caramel. Other indulgent descriptions. A pretty easy-drinking, but complex, sessionable beer (even at its hefty 6.6 abv).
Pour is a dark amber with a light tan head..Nose is rich malt, nutty, sweet hops, earth...Taste is dry, some toffee, soft coffee, dark berries, spice, hop bite, Clean...

Bottle. Dark ruby with a thin eggshell head. Aroma is roasty, nutty, grape and raisin. Taste is fruity and earthy. Slightly bitter and smoky in the finish. Light pillowy mouthfeel with moderate carb. Ok.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is dark amber to medium brown.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (nuts, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

A bit simple but definitely pleasant and nicely quaffable.

The pour looks like a classic, primordial drink - slightly murky maroon with a big tan head that lasts forever. Lots of fruit and bready yeasts on the aroma. On the tongue its sweet with berry fruit flavor that fades into herbal hops. Its dark enough that some roasted notes appear, especially in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel has some surprising alcohol heat for the style. Good interpretation of a rare style, but a bit too boozed up.

Bottle PKGD 06/03/14. Nose is deep caramel, sweet fruit, dark toffee, some chocolate ganache! Pours dark amber-copper, a 50:50 mix, with slow, avg carb and a rocky beige head. Taste is clean and malty, a little flat at times, bumpy with Maillard hills at others, and there are nice flights and flits of dough here and there. Light bitterness (and slightly rubbery) but seems increased in the relatively dry environment. Faint fruitiness but a stronger effect on the tongue, sub-puckering and not tart, but ... curling. Some caramel and toffee, but minimal, no earth, but a hint of smoke or heavy roast. Just a touch of milky, lactose-dripping chocolate. Citrus also but its cast in a complementary role. Id like this is be a little more malt-forward, or at least show more separation between malt and hop bite, but as it is theres a bit of a muddle in the middle of the balance. Not entirely sure what to make of it, would rather have pegged it as a smooth American Brown than an Alt, but its still inviting.
Pour is hazy red/brown with a large off-white head. Aroma and flavor of dark cereal grain, nuts, yeast, and toast. Finish is dry with a bit of alcohol.

deep amber with thin lasting foamybeige head; aroma is mild slightly sweet malty; flava is mild with blend of caramel malt and hops; feels medium decent foamy fizz; finishes dry hoppy bitter some notes of caramel malt

Bottle, Clear dark amber with lasting head and lace.Herbal and fruity cherry and citrus complex aroma with hints of toasted caramel. Roasted nutty caramel with fruity ripe cherry sweetness and roasted woody bitterness with hints of citrus. Fairly light and dry. Good. But who drinks alt beers these days? I wonder how many ratebeer users selected altbier as their favorite style?

Bottle out of the Beer Camp box. I dont think Ive ever had an altbier that I have genuinely enjoyed. This is the first that I would certainly drink again. The aroma to me is something like an English bitter. Its got notes of toffee, modest hops, faint fruity notes and a dash of earth. The body has a rich malty profile. I get suggestions of toast, toffee, figs and a reasonable, though fairly nondescript hoppiness. Its clean and balanced. Neat that its a style I couldnt really get into until this one.

Drank this while getting high as fuck with some of my new neighbors. poured a light brown with a decent white head. malt was there in the nose, but did not have an aggressive aroma overall. toasty caramel with a decent hop balance. thirst quenching and complimented the really good weed my friend Katie sent with me when i moved. not a malt bomb by any stretch, but gave me the notes that i really like.

Bottle from a 12 pack, 
this ale had a clear reddish brown pour and made a one finger faint off-white and off-white head that lowered a bit to cover and sticky ring that left some spots of lacing, the glass was filled with streams of carbonation, there was no sediment in the bottle, 

the nose had malty aromas, some toasted malt, dark bread, caramel like fragrances with faint chocolate hints, some citrus hops with malt and dark bread like sweetness, 

the flavors were malty with hints of chocolate and toasted malt, faint dark fruit of raisin and fig, citrus bitter hops with some brown sugar sweetness, 
the finish had a good bit of hop bitterness with a little carbonation bite from all of the carbonation in this beer, 

the mouth feel was light and foamy on the palate, it felt very creamy, the carbonation was lively to the fizzy side of things, there may have been too much carbonation in this beer, 

the nose was nice and the flavor was good but could have been better if there were less carbonation, it appeared to be fizzy at first but got a little better after the beer had warmed up a bit and the glass was swirled some to lessen the carbonation, I think the carbonation gave a bit of a carbo bite to the drink and added on to the hop bitterness, and it made the drink fizzy, I would have given this beer a better rating with less fizz.

12oz bottle in a tulip. Pours brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of caramel and toffee and pale malts, some floral and lightly citrusy hops, and some dough. Flavor the same. Average texture. Not the best beer in the 12 pack.
solid. Nice altbier-style malty flavor. Smooth, like a lager should be. A hint of spiciness or smokiness perhaps at the end. Very thin mouthfeel. Quite enjoyable.

Deep caramel pour with off white head. Nose comes through with caramel and some fruit sweetness that I cant place, but not bad. Flavor is njoyanke, but not my favorite. Bright crisp malt if that makes sense. Some sweet notes but not as powerful as the nose. Still has some light sweetness of fruit. Not terrible though, just not the best...
7/29/2014. From bottle. Dark copper color with an off-white head. Sweet malty aromas with light fruits. Malty, hoppy flavors, caramel, citrus, dark fruit. Light bitter finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep orange amber with an off-white head. Sweet-scented pale malt aroma, fruity, hinting at candy grape or strawberry/cherry liquorice, with a hoppy tone. Flavors of toasted grains and biscuit and a bit of dark fruit mixed in, accentuated with citrusy hops and a nice bitterness. Great flavor combination. I really like this one.
12oz bottle pours out a amber topped with a small head. Nose is cereal malts spice and fruit. Taste is as the nose with lots of malts.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a nice, dark chestnut brown, with a medium, persistent, beige head. The aroma is pecans, herbs, caramelized sugar, burnt toast, and leather. Sweet and a little roasty, with a mellow bitterness. Medium body, syrupy, and sticky. This is a pretty aggressive altbier; very hoppy and roasted, at least for an altbier.
Bottle. Pours maple syrup amber with a scant off white head. Aroma is cereal and grass. Flavor is caramel, citrus, grassy bitter in the finish. Good balance.
Nice copper color fruity nose with hints of bread. Smooth and somewhat sweet going down with some bitterness at the end.
Draft. Brown pour with tan head. Sweet berry, light sweet malt tones. Flavors are malty, light fruit and has some sweetness.

12 oz. Beautiful clear dark copper-brown body with a lasting quarter inch of creamy foam. Nose is husky grain, toast and unsweetened cocoa. Taste is chestnut, dark toasted bread, dry bitterish grass and some touches of cocoa and sour apple. Medium body is smooth with medium carbonation and a nice balance.

Bottle - Pours deep brown with a foamy light tan head. Nose is a wonderful mix of dry bread, dough, and Noble hops. Mmm...I could smell that all day. Taste is the same--dry bread, light dough yeast, a little bit of fruitiness through the middle and on to the herbal/floral gentle hop finish. Leaves a nutty, malty finish. Smooth on the palate with a medium-thin body. Man, this is good.

Bottle. Pours copper colored with a small foamy head that collects to a nice ring. Aroma is really nice. Cherries, citrus, caramel, bread, flowers, and light cocoa. Tastes nice but more subdued. Cherry flavored candy, bread, and flowers mostly. Some light bitter citrus peel in the finish. Pretty nice altbier.
12oz bottle. Poured a mahogany color with smaller sized off white head. Floral hops, some breadiness, citrus, and caramel.

Clear mahogany pour; plenty of Munich like caramel and raisin malts, surrounded in earth, oak, and weird citrusy hop oils.
This comes through more awkwardly in the flavor with lots of tea and pithiness highlighting the fact that the malt body isnt well developed. The alt flavor of dirty caramel and rich fruit is present, just outmanned and overwhelmed.

This is another extremely hollow for its style example. The flavors are sufficiently warm and balanced, but the depth is never there.

Bottle sample at the SN tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 7/24/14. Pours clear brown with a thick beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel and light fruit. Malty and caramelly flavor with a crisp finish. Nice Altbier.

From a bottle into a Beer Hunter Summer glass. Pours a pretty dark brown. Little bit o head and not much lacing. Mild aroma. Mouthfeel is great. Just great. Taste is subdued. Fruity. Mild but with a lot of nuance and dark molasses flavor but not kick you in the teeth sweetness. Very good. I could dink a few and probably enjoy each one better than the last.

On draught at baileys - pours clear copper with medium head. Nose of grain and grass. Taste is of grain, spice, and grass.

On draught during Sierra Nevada Beer Camp Across America event at Baileys Taproom. Dark brownish amber color. Aroma is toasted caramel corn and grass. Taste is grass, dark caramel, corn, and sweet grain. Flavorful and sweet.

Bottled June 3, 2014.
Appearance: The body is crystal clear with a mahogany body that has red tones through it. The head is tall and pillowy with a light tan hue. This fills out my glass nicely and looks great in it.
Aroma: The aroma is mild, but lovely. Hints of clean bitterness with a complex malt base giving caramel, cocoa and bready aromas. 
Taste: Holy shit was the first words out of my mouth. What a wonderfully lovely beer. The malt base is near thick and very prominent in flavor giving a rich caramel and cocoa base with a bready backing. Overlying that is a clean, slightly bitter orange, hop profile that perfectly balances out the body. The finish is dry, giving some rich malts before giving out. Lingering is a hint of cocoa, a hint of toast and a clean bitterness.
